{{use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{update|date=September 2018}} [[File:P1300182 Paris V place Contrescarpe rwk.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[Place de la Contrescarpe]] in Paris, where the assault took place]] The '''Benalla affair''' ({{lang-fr|affaire Benalla}}) is a political and judicial case involving Alexandre Benalla, who served as a security officer and deputy chief of staff to [[President of France|French President]] [[Emmanuel Macron]]. On 18 July 2018, the newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' identified him in footage as the person who beat up a young protester during the 2018 [[May Day]] demonstrations in Paris while impersonating a police officer.
Following the publication of the report, the Paris public prosecutor opened a preliminary investigation on 19 July concerning "violence, usurpation of the functions of a police officer and using signs reserved for public authorities". On 20 July, the Élysée announced that Benalla would be dismissed. On 22 July, Benalla was placed under formal investigation additionally for "concealment of a violation of professional secrecy" and "concealment of the misuse of images from a video surveillance system". An accomplice, Vincent Crase, was also placed under formal investigation, as well as three police officers for illegally transmitting video surveillance to Benalla. Parts of the French political class media questioned the Élysée's responsibility in the case for its apparent concealment of the case from the public prosecutor.
Both the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] and [[Senate (France)|Senate]] launched parliamentary inquiries into the affair, with [[Minister of the Interior (France)|Interior Minister]] [[Gérard Collomb]], Paris police chief [[Michel Delpuech]], Department of Public Order and Traffic (DOPC) director [[Alain Gibelin]], [[Prime Minister (France)|Prime Minister]] [[Édouard Philippe]], and Élysée chief of staff [[Patrick Strzoda]] among those called to testify. Opposition lawmakers in the National Assembly also announced their intention to submit a [[motion of no confidence]] against the government.
== Background == [[File:Alexandre Benalla.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Alexandre Benalla in 2013]] On 1 May 2018, violence during May Day demonstrations led to significant damage and the arrests of 283 people with 109 taken into custody in Paris, in addition to several injuries. The violence resulted in part from the interruption of the demonstrations by 1,200 "black bloc" protesters.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Julia Pascual|author2=Cécile Bouanchaud|author3=Pierre Bouvier|title=1er Mai : 109 personnes en garde à vue après les violences en marge du cortège parisien|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/05/01/1er-mai-le-defile-parisien-perturbe-par-une-serie-de-violences-200-black-blocs-interpelles_5293042_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=1 May 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
Alexandre Benalla (born 8 September 1991 in [[Évreux]]) was reportedly a [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party]] (PS) activist in [[Eure]], his home department, before offering his services as a bodyguard with the PS, which assigned him to the entourage of [[Martine Aubry]] from 2008 to 2012. He was later assigned to protect [[François Hollande]] as well as, briefly, [[Arnaud Montebourg]]. A week into his assignment, he was dismissed after causing a car accident and wanting to flee from the scene. Following his dismissal, he protected artists before joining the security force of [[Emmanuel Macron]], whom Benalla supported, during his presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Jean-Michel Décugis|author2=Myriam Encaoua|author3=Quentin Laurent|title=Alexandre Benalla, itinéraire d'un impulsif|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/faits-divers/alexandre-benalla-itineraire-d-un-impulsif-20-07-2018-7827393.php|newspaper=Le Parisien|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ce que l'on sait de l'affaire Benalla|url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualites/1/societe/ce-que-l-on-sait-de-l-affaire-benalla_2026896.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=L'Express|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> He also worked with PS deputy [[Pascale Boistard]] as an unpaid parliamentary assistant in 2012 and had access to some areas of the [[Palais Bourbon]].<ref name="Monde20180719">{{cite news|title=Enquête, profil du suspect, réactions politiques… ce que l'on sait de l'affaire Benalla|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/19/enquete-profil-du-suspect-reactions-politiques-ce-que-l-on-sait-de-l-affaire-benalla_5333734_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
From 2010 to 2013, Benalla began his career as a reservist gendarme in Eure under then-platoon commander [[Sébastien Lecornu]], who at the time was a member of the [[Union for a Popular Movement]] (UMP) and member of the cabinet of then-agriculture minister [[Bruno Le Maire]]. Both Lecornu and Le Maire were appointed as ministers in [[Second Philippe government|the government]] assembled after the election of Macron, with Lecornu serving as [[Secretary of State (France)|Secretary of State]] to the [[Ministry of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy|Minister for the Ecological and Inclusive Transition]] and Le Maire becoming [[French Ministry for the Economy and Finance|Minister of Economy and Finance]]. Benalla would later support Le Maire in his bid to lead the party in its [[Union for a Popular Movement leadership election, 2014|2014 leadership election]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Alain Auffray|title=Quand le gendarme Benalla officiait sous les ordres de Lecornu|url=http://www.liberation.fr/politiques/2018/07/20/quand-le-gendarme-benalla-officiait-sous-les-ordres-de-lecornu_1667759|newspaper=Libération|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> On 18 March 2016, Benalla was acquitted following a complaint of violence filed against him in [[Boulogne-Billancourt]] in August 2015 by a woman who stated that she was unable to work for more than 8 days as a result.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Anne Vidalie|author2=Claire Hache|author3=Benoist Fechner|author4=Laurent Léger|title=Benalla, jugé pour violences et relaxé en 2016|url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/fait-divers/benalla-deja-juge-pour-violences-en-2016_2026833.html|newspaper=L'Express|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
His name appeared numerous times in the [[2017 Macron e-mail leaks]], dubbed "MacronLeaks", having procured several non-lethal weapons and riot shields. At the request of the Élysée to aide him in his capacity as a security officer, Benalla was granted a carry license by the Paris police prefecture in October 2017.<ref name="Monde20180719"/> [[Karim Achoui]], the founder of the Muslim Judicial Defense League with whom Benalla was close, made a previous request for a carry permit that was denied in 2013 in his capacity as a lawyer.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alexandre Benalla s'était vu refuser le port d'armes en 2013|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2018/07/20/97001-20180720FILWWW00318-alexandre-benalla-s-etait-vu-refuser-le-port-d-armes-en-2013.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> During a March 2017 campaign event in [[Caen]], he allegedly pushed a [[Public Sénat]] journalist 50 meters and seized his press badge, which granted close access to Macron and his supporters, without giving any explanation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vidéo. Affaire Benalla : un précédent qui aurait dû alerter|url=https://www.publicsenat.fr/article/politique/video-affaire-benalla-un-precedent-qui-aurait-du-alerter-88345|publisher=Public Sénat|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
Benalla seemed to maintain a close relationship with Macron as he was the only member of his cabinet to join a skiing trip at the end of 2017, the only other invitees being his security detail.<ref>{{cite news|author=Laurent Léger|title=Quand Benalla skiait avec Macron|url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/fait-divers/quand-benalla-skiait-avec-macron_2026561.html|newspaper=L'Express|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
== Case == On 18 July 2018, ''Le Monde'' revealed in an article that 26-year-old Alexandre Benalla, who served as a security officer to [[President of France]] [[Emmanuel Macron]] during the [[French presidential election, 2017|2017 presidential campaign]] and was later hired as deputy chief of staff to the president under François-Xavier Lauch, was the person who grabbed a young man by the neck during the May Day demonstrations before hitting him several times in a video taken at the [[Place de la Contrescarpe]] published on Facebook by a [[La France Insoumise]] activist. In the video, Benalla wore a police helmet despite not being a police officer. According to [[Patrick Strzoda]], Benalla asked him for permission to join the police during May Day to observe how a large demonstration was managed. After Strzoda was informed that Benalla had been seen in the videos, Benalla said that he was the individual shown in the videos and Strzoda informed Macron, then in Australia, of the situation. As a result, Benalla was temporarily suspended from 4 to 19 May before being reassigned to the security of events at the [[Élysée Palace]], including the celebration of the victory of the [[France national football team|national football team]] after winning the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] just days before the publication of the report.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ariane Chemin|title=" Le Monde " identifie, sur une vidéo, un collaborateur de Macron frappant un manifestant, le 1er mai, à Paris|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/18/le-monde-identifie-sur-une-video-un-collaborateur-de-m-macron-frappant-un-manifestant-le-1er-mai-a-paris_5333330_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=18 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> However, these claims were questioned by journalists who uncovered photos after the supposed reassignment as part of Macron's entourage.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Emmanuel Fansten|author2=Ismaël Halissat|title=Affaire Benalla : ces photos qui contredisent l'Elysée|url=http://www.liberation.fr/france/2018/07/20/affaire-benalla-ces-photos-qui-contredisent-l-elysee_1667906|newspaper=Libération|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> A second video, showing a different angle of the incident, was posted to Twitter on 19 July, showing Benalla grabbing a woman by the neck and dragging her away before leaving towards the other protester.<ref name="Monde20180719"/>
Benalla was accompanied by Vincent Crase, a reservist gendarme hired by [[La République En Marche!]], who likewise served as a security officer for Macron during the 2017 presidential campaign. Crase, like Benalla, received a 15-day suspension for his involvement in the May Day demonstrations, and remained employed by the party,<ref name="Monde20180719"/> but unlike Benalla had ended "any collaboration" with the office of the presidency.<ref>{{cite news|author=Marie-Alix Dagry|title=Affaire Benalla : Vincent Crase à son tour placé en garde à vue|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/actualite-france/2018/07/19/01016-20180719ARTFIG00184-affaire-benalla-vincent-crase-le-deuxieme-collaborateur-de-macron-mis-en-cause.php|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> A third individual, Philippe Mizerski, was identified; Mizerski, a member of the Department of Public Order and Traffic (DOPC) in Paris was responsible for supervising Benalla's role as an "observer" but did not attempt to stop Benalla from assaulting the protesters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Garde à vue, procédure de licenciement, commission d'enquête : retrouvez le suivi de l'affaire Benalla|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/live/2018/07/20/en-direct-alexandre-benalla-a-ete-place-en-garde-a-vue-et-va-etre-licencie-par-l-elysee_5334037_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref>
On 19 July, the Paris prosecutor announced that it opened a preliminary investigation into incidents of "violence, usurpation of the functions of a police officer and using insignia reserved for public authorities" concerning Alexandre Benalla.<ref>{{cite news|title=Violences sur un manifestant : le parquet ouvre une enquête visant un collaborateur de Macron|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/19/violences-sur-un-manifestant-le-parquet-de-paris-ouvre-une-enquete-preliminaire-visant-un-collaborateur-de-m-macron_5333484_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> Strzoda was heard as a witness in the investigation the same day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : le directeur de cabinet du président Macron a été entendu jeudi comme témoin|url=http://www.europe1.fr/societe/affaire-benalla-le-directeur-de-cabinet-du-president-macron-a-ete-entendu-jeudi-comme-temoin-3715415|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Europe 1|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> [[Minister of the Interior (France)|Minister of the Interior]] [[Gérard Collomb]] also announced that he referred the case to the [[General Inspectorate of the National Police]] (IGPN) and that its report would be published publicly,<ref name="Wintrebert">{{cite news|author=Hugo Wintrebert|title=Affaire Benalla : l'exécutif à la peine|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/19/affaire-benalla-l-executif-a-la-peine_5333723_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> with the IGPN charged with investigating how Benalla and Crase were allowed to participate in overseeing the demonstrations alongside the police. The interior ministry, however, said that no immediate action had been taken against either of the two on 1 May despite having been aware of the incident,<ref name="Monde20180719"/> and [[France Inter]] revealed that Collomb himself was informed about the incident on 2 May before the Élysée took action to suspend Benalla on 3 May.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Cyril Graziani|author2=Yaël Goosz|title=INFO FRANCE INTER. Affaire Benalla : le ministre de l'Intérieur, Gérard Collomb, savait dès le lendemain des faits|url=https://www.francetvinfo.fr/politique/emmanuel-macron/agression-d-un-manifestant-par-un-collaborateur-de-l-elysee/info-france-inter-affaire-benalla-le-ministre-de-l-interieur-gerard-collomb-savait-des-le-lendemain-des-faits_2858847.html|agency=France Inter|publisher=franceinfo|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
On 20 July, the Élysée announced that it had initiated a dismissal procedure against Benalla following the discovery of "new facts" of the case related to the suspension of three police officers – Laurent Simonin, Maxence Creusat, and Jean-Yves Hunault – for apparently passing on surveillance footage to Benella, presumably to help him prepare his defense in what Collomb described as a potentially "serious breach of ethics".<ref name="licenciement">{{cite news|title=L'Élysée engage la procédure de licenciement d'Alexandre Benalla|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/2018/07/20/01002-20180720ARTFIG00079-l-elysee-engage-la-procedure-de-licenciement-d-alexandre-benalla.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> The footage, which was copied by the officers and sent to Benalla the evening the article in ''Le Monde'' was published, depicts another angle not shown by the other videos and should theoretically not have existed given that video footage older than a month was supposed to be automatically erased.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Salomé Legrand|author2=Noémi Marois|title=INFORMATION EUROPE 1 - Affaire Benalla : trois policiers suspendus pour avoir transmis les images de vidéosurveillance à Alexandre Benalla|url=http://www.europe1.fr/faits-divers/information-europe-1-affaire-benalla-trois-policiers-dont-deux-commissaires-suspendus-pour-avoir-duplique-une-video-interne-3715196|publisher=Europe 1|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> After obtaining the footage, Benalla reportedly shared it with [[Ismaël Emelien]], a political advisor close to Macron, and other Élysée viewed this footage as well.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla: le conseiller Ismaël Emelien a visionné les vidéos obtenues illégalement|url=https://www.bfmtv.com/politique/affaire-benalla-l-elysee-a-eu-en-sa-possession-les-videos-obtenues-illegalement-1495324.html|publisher=BFM TV|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> The Paris prosecutor office took both Benella and Crase into custody in the morning.<ref name="licenciement"/> A photo obtained of Benalla's official car in a parking lot before it was removed on 19 July showed the vehicle equipped with police devices despite not belonging to the police.<ref>{{cite news|author=Dominique Rizet|title=La voiture de fonction d'Alexandre Benalla était équipée d'accessoires policiers|url=https://www.bfmtv.com/police-justice/la-voiture-de-fonction-d-alexandre-benalla-etait-equipee-d-accessoires-policiers-1492363.html|publisher=BFM TV|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> ''Le Monde'' reported on 20 July that Benalla declared his official residence from 9 July as the [[Palais de l'Alma]] at 11 quai Branly, a dependency of the Élysée,<ref>{{cite news|author1=François Krug|author2=Ariane Chemin|title=Alexandre Benalla est logé quai Branly, dans une dépendance de l'Elysée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/20/alexandre-benalla-est-loge-quai-branly-dans-une-dependance-de-l-elysee_5334081_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> with 180,000 euros earmarked to house Benalla, according to a report in ''[[L'Express]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Laurent Léger|author2=Benoist Fechner|title=Benalla, du pouvoir et des privilèges|url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/politique/alexandre-benalla-les-secrets-du-m-securite-du-president_2027183.html|newspaper=L'Express|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
On 22 July, Benalla was placed under formal investigation additionally for "concealment of a violation of professional secrecy" and "concealment of the misuse of images from a video surveillance system", in addition to Crase and the three suspended police officers. The apparent victims in the videos were also identified and asked to testify at a later date.<ref name="Monde20180722">{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : cinq mises en examen, des faits " inacceptables " selon Emmanuel Macron|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/22/affaire-benalla-l-enquete-a-ete-confiee-a-un-juge-d-instruction_5334602_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=22 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> On 23 July, Benalla's lawyers (Laurent-Franck Lienard and Audrey Gadot) issued a statement – the first since the beginning of the affair – saying that Benalla was "stunned by the media and political usage" of his actions during the May Day demonstrations and that he "took the initiative to lend a hand" by helping to "control" what they described as "two particularly virulent individuals".<ref>{{cite news|author=Georges Brenier|title=DOCUMENT TF1 - Les avocats d'Alexandre Benalla s'expriment pour la première fois sur l'affaire|url=https://www.lci.fr/justice/document-tf1-les-avocats-d-alexandre-benalla-s-expriment-pour-la-premiere-fois-sur-l-affaire-2094004.html|publisher=LCI|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> Benalla's office at the Élysée was subject to a police raid lasting several hours on 25 July.<ref>{{cite news|title=Le bureau d'Alexandre Benalla à l'Elysée a été perquisitionné|url=http://www.europe1.fr/politique/perquisition-en-cours-du-bureau-de-benalla-a-lelysee-3719279|publisher=Europe 1|date=25 July 2018|accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
On 27 July, ''[[Libération]]'' published a video showing that Benalla and Crase were involved in another demonstrator's arrest several hours before, in the [[Jardin des plantes]], ordering one of the demonstrators to remove photographs and videos she filmed.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Willy Le Devin|author2=Ismaël Halissat|title=1er Mai : Benalla et Crase impliqués dans une autre interpellation|url=http://www.liberation.fr/france/2018/07/27/1er-mai-benalla-et-crase-impliques-dans-une-autre-interpellation_1669273|newspaper=Libération|date=27 July 2018|accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref>
== Reactions == Members of the majority in the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] were reportedly "stunned" by the revelations. While many avoided contact with the press and others deflected media inquiries by referring them to statements made by the Élysée, some [[La République En Marche group (National Assembly)|La République En Marche]] deputies implied that the two-week suspension of Benalla was too lenient a response to his conduct.<ref>{{cite news|author=Manon Rescan|title=Les députés macronistes " abasourdis " par l'affaire Benalla|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/19/les-deputes-macronistes-abasourdis-par-l-affaire-benalla_5333704_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> The revelations came amid the examination in the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] of amendments to the proposed constitutional revision on 19 July, with opposition deputies frequently interrupting the session to demand the creation of an investigative committee into the case.<ref>{{cite news|author=Alexandre Lemarié|title=L'affaire Benalla parasite l'examen de la révision constitutionnelle à l'Assemblée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/19/l-affaire-benalla-parasite-l-examen-de-la-reforme-constitutionnelle-a-l-assemblee_5333717_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> The opposition accused the government of being too lenient in its sanctions against Benalla, and of failing to inform the public prosecutor as required under article 40 of the code of criminal procedure, which stipulates that any public official or civil servant who becomes aware of a crime or misdemeanor is to immediately inform the public prosecutor of the incident.<ref name="Monde20180719"/> The affair eventually forced the government to suspend the examination of the constitutional revision on 22 July.<ref>{{cite news|title=Le gouvernement suspend l'examen de la révision constitutionnelle jusqu'à nouvel ordre|url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualites/1/societe/le-gouvernement-suspend-l-examen-de-la-revision-constitutionnelle-jusqu-a-nouvel-ordre_2027075.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=L'Express|date=22 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref>
Asked about the case while visiting [[Dordogne]], [[Emmanuel Macron]] responded that the Republic was "unalterable" and told a journalist that "I did not come to see you, I came here to see Mr. Mayor."<ref name="Wintrebert"/> On 20 July, Macron failed to hold a joint press conference, as customary following visits from other heads of state, after meeting with [[President of Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani President]] [[Ilham Aliyev]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Le point sur l'affaire Benalla, quarante-huit heures après les premières révélations|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/20/le-point-sur-l-affaire-benalla-quarante-huit-heures-apres-les-premieres-revelations_5334207_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> A video of less than 2 minutes long was sent to media representatives by Élysée spokesman [[Bruno Roger-Petit]] on 19 July, prompting criticism regarding the Élysée's communication strategy throughout the affair,<ref>{{cite news|author=Aurélien Viers|title=Affaire Benalla : retour sur l'étrange communication de crise de Bruno Roger-Petit|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/affaire-benalla-retour-sur-l-etrange-communication-de-crise-de-bruno-roger-petit-21-07-2018-7828815.php|newspaper=Le Parisien|date=21 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> and journalists and commentators castigated Macron for failing to explain himself.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : la presse fustige " le Rambo " et " le mutique " de l'Elysée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/21/affaire-benalla-la-presse-fustige-le-rambo-et-le-mutique-de-l-elysee_5334431_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=21 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Macron called a crisis meeting with members of the government on the evening of 22 July.<ref name="Monde20180722"/> His [[Twitter]] account, usually active, fell silent for four days until returning to express solidarity with Greece during the [[2018 Attica wildfires]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Emmanuel Macron sort du silence… en tweetant sur les incendies en Grèce|url=http://www.europe1.fr/politique/emmanuel-macron-sort-du-silence-en-tweetant-sur-les-incendies-en-grece-3718064|publisher=Europe 1|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> On 24 July, Macron broke his silence on the affair and spoke before lawmakers from his party, stating that he alone bore responsibility and that no members of his cabinet had ever been above the law.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : "Le responsable, c'est moi", déclare Emmanuel Macron devant les élus de la majorité|url=https://www.francetvinfo.fr/politique/emmanuel-macron/agression-d-un-manifestant-par-un-collaborateur-de-l-elysee/affaire-benalla-le-responsable-c-est-moi-declare-emmanuel-macron-face-a-la-majorite_2865345.html|publisher=franceinfo|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
[[Benoît Hamon]] demanded the resignation of Collomb as interior minister, while Socialist [[First Secretary of the French Socialist Party|leader]] [[Olivier Faure]] did not exclude the possibility of pressing for him to resign should he fail to give a sufficient explanation.<ref name="Faure">{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla: une démission de Gérard Collomb dans la balance pour Faure (PS)|url=https://www.nouvelobs.com/politique/20180720.AFP3966/affaire-benalla-une-demission-de-gerard-collomb-dans-la-balance-pour-faure-ps.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=L'Obs|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> [[Jean-Luc Mélenchon]], president of the [[La France Insoumise group]] in the National Assembly, announced that he intended to attempt to submit a vote of no confidence against the government,<ref name="Monde20180719"/> and said that the affair was "at the level of [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]]".<ref>{{cite news|author=Astrid de Villaines|title=Jean-Luc Mélenchon : " Cette affaire est du niveau du Watergate "|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/21/jean-luc-melenchon-cette-affaire-est-du-niveau-du-watergate_5334397_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=21 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Faure also favored a motion of no confidence in the case that unless a clear explanation was given, but appeared reluctant to sign on to any motion proposed by Mélenchon.<ref name="Faure"/> On 24 July, [[Christian Jacob (politician)|Christian Jacob]] of [[The Republicans (France)|The Republicans]] (LR) announced that his [[The Republicans group (National Assembly)|group]], with 103 members, would submit a motion of no confidence (which requires 58 signatures) against the government, though he acknowledged that the vote would not succeed given the government's majority. Mélenchon's group, with 17 deputies, would not have been able to submit one without the support of other deputies, and FI deputy [[Alexis Corbière]] subsequently announced that the group would be prepared to sign a LR-submitted motion.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ambre Lepoivre|title=Affaire Benalla : les députés LR vont déposer une motion de censure|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/affaire-benalla-les-deputes-lr-vont-deposer-une-motion-de-censure-24-07-2018-7831878.php|newspaper=Le Parisien|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> The LR group officially submitted a motion of no confidence on 26 July,<ref>{{cite news|title=Benalla: la motion de censure LR débattue mardi, peut-être avec une motion de gauche|url=https://www.nouvelobs.com/politique/20180726.AFP4283/benalla-la-motion-de-censure-lr-debattue-mardi-peut-etre-avec-une-motion-de-gauche.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=L'Obs|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> followed by the three groups on the left – the [[New Left group|New Left]], [[La France Insoumise group|La France Insoumise]], and [[Democratic and Republican Left group|Democratic and Republican Left]] – filing a joint motion on 27 July to be debated on 31 July, followed by the right's on 2 August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : les trois groupes de gauche déposent une motion de censure commune|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/27/benalla-le-ps-le-pcf-et-lfi-deposent-une-motion-de-censure-commune_5336854_823448.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Monde|date=27 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref>
In his first public interview since the story broke, Benalla said that he made a "mistake", that he was qualified to carry a weapon as a reservist gendarme, acknowledged tensions with the [[Groupe de sécurité de la présidence de la République|Security Group for the Presidency of the Republic]] (GSPR), that he requested housing of only 80 square meters as opposed the 300 reported by ''L'Express'', that he was invited by Simonin to observe the May Day protests, and that he did not request the video surveillance footage of the incident procured by three police officers.<ref>{{cite news|author=Aurore Coulaud|title=Interview d'Alexandre Benalla au "Monde" : sa version et ses incohérences|url=http://www.liberation.fr/france/2018/07/26/interview-d-alexandre-benalla-au-monde-sa-version-et-ses-incoherences_1668949|newspaper=Libération|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> SMS messages obtained by ''Le Monde'' published on 26 July appeared to indicate that Simonin invited Benalla to the May Day protests.<ref>{{cite news|title=Un échange de SMS montre comment M. Benalla a été invité à la manifestation du 1er mai|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/police-justice/article/2018/07/26/un-echange-de-sms-montre-comment-m-benalla-a-ete-invite-a-la-manifestation-du-1er-mai_5336346_1653578.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> Interviewed on [[TF1]] on 27 July, Benalla insisted he did nothing wrong and that he was acting as a "citizen" against those he considered to be "delinquents".<ref>{{cite news|author=Nicolas Berrod|title=Alexandre Benalla : "Je n'ai rien fait de répréhensible"|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/benalla-je-n-ai-rien-fait-de-reprehensible-27-07-2018-7835916.php|newspaper=Le Parisien|date=27 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref>
=== Parliamentary inquiries === On the evening of 19 July, the Law Committee of the National Assembly headed by [[Yaël Braun-Pivet]] voted to open a parliamentary inquiry into the case lasting one month with the agreement of all group presidents in the National Assembly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : l'Assemblée met en place une commission d'enquête|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/19/affaire-benalla-l-assemblee-met-en-place-une-commission-d-enquete_5333783_3224.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Monde|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> [[Minister of the Interior (France)|Minister of the Interior]] [[Gérard Collomb]] was to be called to testify before the National Assembly for its inquiry;<ref name="licenciement"/> however, the majority and opposition on 20 July failed to agree on a timetable, with the prior proposing 21 July and the latter 23 July.<ref>{{cite news|title=Benalla: la commission d'enquête échoue à se mettre d'accord sur un calendrier d'auditions|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2018/07/20/97001-20180720FILWWW00348-benalla-la-commission-d-enquete-a-l-assemblee-echoue-a-se-mettre-d-accord-sur-un-calendrier-d-auditions.php|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Eventually, the committee agreed to hear Collomb on 23 July, followed by Paris police chief [[Michel Delpuech]] several hours later, though co-rapporteur [[Guillaume Larrivé]] of [[The Republicans (France)|The Republicans]] (LR) wished to also interview both Benalla and Crase as well as [[Christophe Castaner]], [[Alexis Kohler]], and Bruno Roger-Petit.<ref name="JDD20180721">{{cite news|author=Anne-Charlotte Dusseaulx|title=Alexandre Benalla : le ministre Gérard Collomb sera auditionné lundi à l'Assemblée, mardi au Sénat|url=https://www.lejdd.fr/politique/alexandre-benalla-le-ministre-gerard-collomb-auditionne-lundi-a-lassemblee-mardi-au-senat-3715949|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Journal du Dimanche|date=21 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> The groups disagreed on the publicity of the hearings, with the opposition calling for open hearings.<ref name="Monde20180721">{{cite news|author=Manon Rescan|title=La mise sur pied de la commission d'enquête Benalla à l'Assemblée tourne au fiasco|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2018/07/21/la-mise-sur-pied-de-la-commission-d-enquete-benalla-a-l-assemblee-tourne-au-fiasco_5334302_3224.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=21 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Though the opposition also called for [[Prime Minister of France|Prime Minister]] [[Édouard Philippe]] to speak before the National Assembly, he demurred, justifying his absence by citing his scheduled travel to watch the [[2018 Tour de France]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : réclamé à l'Assemblée, Philippe "continue son agenda" sur le Tour de France|url=http://www.europe1.fr/politique/affaire-benalla-reclame-a-lassemblee-philippe-continue-son-agenda-sur-le-tour-de-france-3715487|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Europe 1|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Though numerous opposition politicians also called for Macron himself to testify, legal experts disagreed on whether such an intervention was permitted under the [[Constitution of France|constitution]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : Emmanuel Macron peut-il être auditionné par l'Assemblée ?|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2018/07/23/25001-20180723ARTFIG00269-affaire-benalla-emmanuel-macron-peut-il-etre-auditionne-par-l-assemblee.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref>
In his testimony on 23 July, Collomb blamed the Paris police, saying that he was aware of Benalla's actions but did not alert the judiciary because it was not within his responsibility to do so. He said that he believed that appropriate action (i.e., the two-week suspension of Benalla) had been taken by the Élysée, and also said that he had never discussed the affair with Macron until the day before his testimony, instead saying that Macron was "preoccupied by the constitutional reform", triggering laughter among the deputies present.<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : les cinq éléments-clés de l'audition de Collomb à l'Assemblée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/23/affaire-benalla-les-cinq-elements-cles-de-l-audition-de-gerard-collomb-a-l-assemblee_5334952_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> Article 40 of the code of criminal procedure, however, makes no hierarchical stipulations, and there exists no such limitation prohibiting officials from reporting crimes not committed by subordinates.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Maxime Vaudano|author2=Adrien Sénécat|title=Affaire Benalla : les six failles des réponses de Gérard Collomb|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/les-decodeurs/article/2018/07/23/affaire-benalla-les-six-failles-des-reponses-de-gerard-collomb_5335003_4355770.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> According to Delpuech, Laurent Simonin – one of the officers suspended for transmitting video surveillance footage to Benalla – granted permission to Benalla to observe the demonstration of the police while he himself was unaware until being informed of the incident at a later point, and pinned the transmission of these tapes upon "unhealthy cronyism".<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : ce qu'il faut retenir de l'audition du préfet de police Michel Delpuech à l'Assemblée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/police-justice/article/2018/07/23/affaire-benalla-ce-qu-il-faut-retenir-de-l-audition-du-prefet-de-police-michel-delpuech-a-l-assemblee_5335058_1653578.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> ''Le Monde'' identified several contradictions between the testimony of Collomb and Delpuech, namely related to when and how the prior was informed about the incident.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Jérémie Baruch|author2=Maxime Vaudano|author3=Adrien Sénécat|title=Affaire Benalla : les contradictions du ministre et du préfet sur la remontée des informations|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/les-decodeurs/article/2018/07/23/affaire-benalla-les-contradictions-du-ministre-et-du-prefet-sur-la-remontee-des-informations_5335077_4355770.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> [[Alain Gibelin]], director of the DOPC, stated that Benalla had "no authorization" to be present as an observer at the demonstration, countering previous claims,<ref>{{cite news|title=Benalla n'avait "aucune autorisation" et participait à des réunions malgré sa "suspension"|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/faits-divers/benalla-n-avait-aucune-autorisation-de-la-prefecture-de-police-23-07-2018-7830987.php|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Parisien|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> though later rescinded his initial response indicating that the Élysée had lied about Benalla's suspension and affirmed that he had misheard the dates.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Arthur Berdah|author2=Christophe Cornevin|title=Suspension de Benalla : Alain Gibelin revient sur ses déclarations dans une lettre|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2018/07/24/25001-20180724ARTFIG00068-suspension-de-benalla-alain-gibelin-revient-sur-ses-declarations-dans-une-lettre.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref>
Speaking before both chambers on 24 July, Philippe argued that the penalty imposed upon Benalla was appropriate and said that the case did not constitute a state scandal.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Arthur Berdah|author2=Pierre Lepelletier|author3=Loris Boichot|title=Pour Édouard Philippe, l'affaire Benalla n'est "pas une affaire d'État"|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2018/07/24/25001-20180724ARTFIG00210-pour-edouard-philippe-l-affaire-benalla-n-est-pas-une-affaire-d-etat.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> In the following hearing, chief of staff Strzoda said that he was the individual who made the decision suspend Benalla, with the suspension implemented after Macron was later informed by Kohler while in Australia. He also said that he did not deem the information he received from the IGPN regarding Benalla sufficient to report under article 40,<ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Benalla : ce qu'il faut retenir de l'audition du directeur de cabinet d'Emmanuel Macron|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/24/affaire-benalla-ce-qu-il-faut-retenir-de-l-audition-du-directeur-de-cabinet-d-emmanuel-macron_5335449_823448.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Monde|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> and categorically denied the "rumors" regarding benefits and privileges reportedly afforded to Benalla;<ref>{{cite news|title=Salaire, voiture, logement : Patrick Strzoda relativise les avantages de Benalla|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2018/07/24/25001-20180724ARTFIG00276-salaire-voiture-logement-patrick-strzoda-relativise-les-avantages-de-benalla.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> however, he refused to give the amount of his salary or the details of his apartment.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Pierre Alonso|author2=Ismaël Halissat|title=Affaire Benalla : le bon soldat Strzoda|url=http://www.liberation.fr/france/2018/07/24/affaire-benalla-le-bon-soldat-strzoda_1668639|newspaper=Libération|quote=Etait-il rémunéré 10000 euros par mois? «C'est faux!» s'exclame le directeur de cabinet, tout en refusant de donner le montant du salaire de l'intéressé. Allait-il s'installer dans un duplex de 200 m2? «C'est faux!» répète-t-il, sans que l'on sache s'il dément l'installation prochaine ou la taille du logement|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref> Testifying before the Senate on 25 July, Strzoda revealed that Benalla received a full salary for the month of May during which he was suspended, and his days of leave were instead reduced to compensate for this.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suspendu quinze jours, Benalla a été intégralement payé en mai|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/25/suspendu-quinze-jours-alexandre-benalla-a-malgre-tout-ete-integralement-paye-en-mai_5335841_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=25 July 2018|accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref> Kohler echoed earlier answers, saying he believed that Benalla's punishment was sufficient given the facts known at the time and that article 40 did not need to be invoked; he also declined to provide Benalla's salary, details of his housing, carry permit, and other assets.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Pierre Lepelletier|author2=Matthieu Desmoulins|author3=Loris Boichot|title=Affaire Benalla : ce qu'il faut retenir de l'audition d'Alexis Kohler par le Sénat|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2018/07/26/25001-20180726ARTFIG00135-affaire-benalla-ce-qu-il-faut-retenir-de-l-audition-d-alexis-kohler-par-le-senat.php|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> Meanwhile, the atmosphere of the National Assembly's investigation deteriorated as tensions grew between members of the majority and opposition, with the latter alleging that Braun-Pivet attempted to impede its progress and avoid hearing staff at the Élysée, Interior Ministry, La République En Marche, and police unions, some of which had been already interviewed by the Senate. On 26 July, Larrivé announced that he suspended his participation in the investigation, considering it a farce faced against the Élysée's apparent efforts to hinder its progress,<ref>{{cite news|title=Comment la commission d'enquête de l'Assemblée nationale a fini par exploser autour de l'affaire Benalla|url=https://www.francetvinfo.fr/politique/emmanuel-macron/agression-d-un-manifestant-par-un-collaborateur-de-l-elysee/comment-la-commission-d-enquete-de-l-assemblee-nationale-se-dechire-autour-de-l-affaire-benalla_2867627.html|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=franceinfo|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> and the rest of the opposition subsequently quit the inquiry.<ref>{{cite news|author=Manon Rescan|title=Affaire Benalla : l'opposition suspend sa participation à la commission d'enquête de l'Assemblée|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2018/07/26/affaire-benalla-le-corapporteur-lr-suspend-sa-participation-a-la-commission-d-enquete_5336339_823448.html|newspaper=Le Monde|date=26 July 2018|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref>
The Law Committee in the [[Senate (France)|Senate]], presided over by [[Philippe Bas]], also opened a parliamentary inquiry into the case and will interview Collomb in a public hearing on 24 July;<ref>{{cite news|author=Margaux Lannuzel|title=Comment les parlementaires vont se pencher sur l'affaire Benalla|url=http://www.europe1.fr/politique/comment-les-parlementaires-vont-se-pencher-sur-laffaire-benalla-3715478|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Europe 1|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> unlike the assembly's inquiry, the Senate's will have six months to investigate.<ref name="Monde20180721"/> The Senate committee will also interview Delpuech, [[Éric Morvan]],<ref name="JDD20180721"/> Alexis Kohler, [[Patrick Strzoda]], Christophe Castaner, and other related individuals in the course of its investigation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Benalla: le Sénat auditionne jeudi le secrétaire général de l'Elysée|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2018/07/23/97001-20180723FILWWW00157-affaire-benalla-audition-par-le-senat-d-alexis-kohler-jeudi.php|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=23 July 2018|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref>

'''Bhāruci's''' commentary ([[bhashya]]) on the [[Manu Smrti]], or [[Laws of Manu]], is part of the corpus of [[Dharmaśāstra]] texts available to us today. It is the oldest commentary on Manu that we know of,<ref>{{cite book |last= Lingat |first= Robert |authorlink= Robert Lingat |others= Translated from French with Additions by [[J Duncan M Derrett|J.D.M.Derrett]] |title= The Classical Law of India |trans-title=|url= https://www.worldcat.org/title/classical-law-of-india/oclc/660299&referer=brief_results |date= |origyear= originally published in French in 1967 |year= English translation 1973 |publisher= University of California Press |location= Berkeley |language= |isbn= 9781882239085 |quote= |ref= |laysummary= |laydate= }} </ref> and is one of the sources used by [[Medhātithi]], another major commentator on the Manu Smṛti.
==Dating and Historical Context== Very little is known about the date or historical context in which Bhāruci was writing, but [[P. V. Kane]] argues that it cannot have been written after 1050 CE because Vijñāneśvara, the author of the {{IAST|[[Mitākṣarā]]}}, a famous commentary on the {{IAST|[[Yājñavalkya Smṛti]]}}, mentions Bhāruci's commentary in his writing.<ref>Kane, P. V., ''History of Dharmaśāstra'', (Poona: Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, 1975), Volume I, Part I, 566.</ref> Viśvarūpa, another commentator on the [[Yājñavalkya Smṛti| ''{{IAST|Yājñavalka Smṛti}}'']], also uses Bhāruci as a source. [[Patrick Olivelle]] places Bhāruci in the 8th century CE,<ref name="ReferenceA">Olivelle, Patrick, "Dharmaśāstra: A Literary History", 29.</ref> while [[J. Duncan M. Derrett]] places him between 600-650 CE.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> There are two known authors named Bhāruci placed in about the same period of time, one who wrote on ''Dharmaśāstra'' and one who was a jurist, and Kane posits that they were in fact the same person because it is unlikely that there were two famous writers with the same name writing at the same time.<ref>Kane, P. V., ''History of Dharmaśāstra'', (Poona: Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, 1975), Volume I, Part I, 567.</ref>
==Topics== The main content of Bhāruci's commentary deals with the duties of a king, particularly regarding whether or not the king can be a source of [[dharma]]. Bhāruci's view as discussed by Derrett was that the king did not have any legislative power, but he did have "the power to issue regulations and edicts of a temporary character or for the purpose of facilitating objects already inculcated by the ''dharmaśāstra''."<ref>[[J Duncan M Derrett|Derrett, J. Duncan M.]], "Bhāruci on the Royal Regulative Power in India", ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'', Vol. 84, No. 4, (1964), 392.</ref> Kane agrees, stating that "the king is not the source of the rules of ''Dharma'', but it is śāstra that defines the rules binding on the different [[varnas]] (classes) and [[ashramas]] (stages of man's life)."<ref>Kane, P. V., ''History of Dharmaśāstra'', (Poona: Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, 1975), Volume I, Part I, 569-570.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

The '''Canada Consumer Product Safety Act''' was a Canadian act that passed into law by the [[Government of Canada]] on December 14, 2010. This law replaced Part I of the Hazardous Products Act.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/politics/story/2010/12/14/con-consumer-safety-act.html Consumer safety bill passes Parliament]</ref> It was originally introduced in the 2nd session of the [[39th Parliament of Canada]] as '''Bill C-52'''. It died in committee when the [[2008 Canadian federal election]] was called, but was reintroduced in the 2nd session of the [[40th Parliament of Canada]] as '''Bill C-6''' and was passed by both houses of Parliament but did not receive royal assent before Parliament was [[prorogation in Canada|prorogued]]. It was introduced for a third time in the 3rd session of the 40th Parliament as '''Bill C-36'''.
The legislative package proposes amendments to the Hazardous Products Act (HPA), and would move continue consumer products to be regulated under the proposed Canada Consumer Product Safety Act. These bills are a result of increased consumer concern over consumer products, such as children's toys, which have been the subject of recalls over the past few years. Canada's Hazardous Products Act has not been updated in over 40 years. Canada's regulatory system has not kept pace with the global economy and increasing amounts of international trade. The Minister of Health, for example, currently doesn't have the power to force recall of faulty or counterfeit products in Canada.
== Support for improving Consumer Product Safety == [[Health Canada]] consulted widely with industry and consumer groups over a period of several years before bringing forward the [[Consumer Product Safety Action Plan]].<ref>[http://www.healthycanadians.ca/pr-rp/dpaper-papier_e.html Consumer Product Safety Action Plan]</ref>
Health Canada regularly issues warnings, advisories and information updates to advise consumers of products on the market which contain toxic substances such as [[lead]], [[mercury (element)|mercury]] or [[arsenic]]; or are otherwise contaminated by dangerous and unhealthy substances. However under the previous legislation, the [[Minister of Health]] has no power to compel recall of these products. For example, Health Canada posted just over 300 recall notices in 2009. Roughly one third of these were for children's products. In 2009, about 1.5 million consumers were affected by crib recalls alone.

{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Charlton v. Kelly |ArgueDate=April 18 |ArgueYear=1913 |DecideDate=June 10 |DecideYear=1913 |FullName=Paul Charlton, as Next Friend of Porter ter Charlton, Appt., v. James J. Kelly, Sheriff of Hudson County, New Jersey, et al. |USVol=229 |USPage=447 |ParallelCitations=33 S. Ct. 945; 57 [[L. Ed.]] 1274 |Prior= |Subsequent= |Holding=Court recognized authority of the executive department to waive a breach of treaty by Italy and to remain bound thereby. |SCOTUS=1912-1914 |LawsApplied= }} '''''Charlton v. Kelly''''', 229 U.S. 447 (1913), is a case pertaining to [[extradition]] of a U.S. citizen to [[Italy]].<ref>{{ussc|name=Charlton v. Kelly|volume=229|page=447|pin=448-50|year=1913}}.</ref> In 1910, [[Porter Charlton]] confessed in New York to having murdered his wife in Italy.<ref>''Charlton'', 229 U.S. at 470.</ref> The Italian vice consul requested Charlton's extradition.<ref>''Charlton'', 229 U.S. at 448, 470-71.</ref> Hon. John A. Blair, one of the judges of the Circuit Court of the United States for the district of New Jersey, suspended Charlton's petition for a writ of [[habeas corpus]] and a warrant was issued for his arrest.<ref>''Charlton'', 229 U.S. at 448-49.</ref> This order for extradition was approved by [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Philander C. Knox]].<ref>''Charlton'', 229 U.S. at 465.</ref>
==Opinion of the Court== In an opinion written by [[Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court|Justice]] [[Horace Harmon Lurton]], the Court held that the United States had the right to waive a breach of its extradition treaty with Italy, and by waiving the breach, the countries would remain bound by the treaty.<ref>''Charlton'', 229 U.S. at 475-76.</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox official post |post = Chief Justice of India |body = |image = Ranjan Gogoi at 4th Foundation Day function of the National Green Tribunal.jpg |insignia = Emblem of the Supreme Court of India.svg |insigniasize = 100px |insigniacaption = Emblem of the Supreme Court of India |incumbent = [[Ranjan Gogoi]] |incumbentsince = 3 October 2018 |department = [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]] |seat = [[New Delhi]] |nominator = Collegium of the Supreme Court |appointer = [[President of India]] |termlength = till the age of 65 yrs<ref>{{cite web|url=http://supremecourtofindia.nic.in/judges/judges.htm|title=Supreme Court of India - CJI & Sitting Judges|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> |constituting_instrument = [[Constitution of India]] <small>(under Article 124)</small> |formation = {{start date and age|df=yes|1950}} |first = Justice [[H. J. Kania]] <small>(26 January 1950 – 6 November 1951)</small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://supremecourtofindia.nic.in/judges/rcji.htm|title=Supreme Court of India Retired Hon'ble the Chief Justices' of India|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> |abbreviation = CJI |salary = {{INRConvert|280000}} (per month)<ref name="salary hike for judges">{{cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/supreme-court-high-court-judges-get-nearly-200-salary-hike/story-sRMnVUhOLqAgXJaVOf0VcN.html|title=Supreme Court, High Court judges get nearly 200% salary hike|newspaper=[[The Hindustan Times]]|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=30 January 2018}}</ref> |website = [http://www.supremecourtofindia.nic.in/ Supreme Court of India] }} {{Courts of India}} The '''Chief Justice of India''' (CJI) is the head of the [[judiciary of India]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://14.139.60.114:8080/jspui/bitstream/123456789/15149/1/015_Chief%20Justice%20Sinha-A%20Review%20of%20Some%20of%20his%20Decisions%20(145-152).pdf#page=5|title=Chief Justice Sinha - A Review of Some of His Decisions (page 5 of 8)|last=Narasimham|first=R L, Justice (CJ, Orissa H. C.)|date=|website=Indian Law Institute|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and the [[Supreme Court of India]]. The CJI also heads their administrative functions.
As head of the supreme court, the chief justice is responsible for the allocation of cases and appointment of constitutional benches which deal with important matters of law.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.livelaw.in/new-captain-ship-change-sailing-rules-soon/|title=New Captain Of The Ship, Change In Sailing Rules Soon?|last=Saxena|first=Namit|date=23 December 2016|work=|newspaper=Live Law|language=en-US|access-date=24 December 2016|via=}}</ref> In accordance with Article 145 of the [[Constitution of India]] and the Supreme Court Rules of Procedure of 1966, the Chief Justice allocates all work to the other judges who are bound to refer the matter back to him or her (for re-allocation) in any case where they require it to be looked into by a larger bench of more judges.
On the administrative side, the Chief Justice carries out the following functions: maintenance of the roster; appointment of court officials and general and miscellaneous matters relating to the supervision and functioning of the Supreme Court.
It has been an unbroken convention for decades now, to appoint the senior-most judge of the supreme court as the CJI.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.criticaltwenties.in/lawthejudiciary/how-india-missed-getting-its-first-woman-chief-justice-india|title=How India missed getting its first woman Chief Justice India|last=Alok|first=|date=26 November 2010|website=Critical Twenties|publisher=|access-date=4 September 2016}}</ref>
The present CJI is Justice [[Ranjan Gogoi]], and is the 46th CJI since January 1950, the year the Constitution came into effect and the supreme court came into being. He succeeded Justice [[Dipak Misra]] on 2 October 2018, and will remain in office till 17 November 2019, the day he retires on turning 65 years in age.
==Appointment== Article 124 of the Constitution of India provides for the manner of appointing judges to the Supreme Court. Though no specific provision exists in the Constitution for appointing the Chief Justice, who, as a result, is appointed like the other judges<ref name="Article 124, Constitution of India">{{cite web|title=Article 124, Constitution of India|url=http://www.vakilno1.com/bareacts/Constitution/S124.htm|publisher=Vakilno1.com|accessdate=11 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226003752/http://vakilno1.com/bareacts/Constitution/S124.htm|archivedate=26 December 2010}}</ref> conventionally, the outgoing CJI recommends the name of the senior-most judge (i.e. by date of appointment to the Supreme Court) for appointment by the [[President of India]], as his successor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Venkatesan|first1=J.|title=TS Thakur to succeed HL Dattu as new Chief Justice of India|url=http://www.asianage.com/india/ts-thakur-succeed-hl-dattu-new-chief-justice-india-412|accessdate=5 November 2015|work=Asian Age|date=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thewire.in/88687/seniority-norm-cji-appointment-thakur-khehar/|title=Seniority as the Norm to Appoint India's Chief Justice is a Dubious Convention|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=The WIre|access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref>
==Removal== Article 124(4) of Constitution of India lays down the procedure for removal of a Judge of Supreme Court which is applicable to Chief Justice as well. Once appointed, the Chief Justice remains in the office until the age of 65 years. He can be removed only through a process of [[impeachment]] by [[Parliament of India|Parliament]] as follows:
{{Quotation|A Judge of the Supreme Court shall not be removed from his office except by an order of the President passed after an address by each House of Parliament supported by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members of that House present and voting has been presented to the President in the same session for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity.|Article 124(4), [[Constitution of India]]| <ref name="Article 124, Constitution of India"/>}} <!-- You should not put quotation marks around the quote. -->
==Acting President== The President (Discharge of Functions) Act, 1969 of India provides that the Chief Justice of India (CJI) shall act as the President of India in the event of the offices of both the President and the Vice President being vacant. When [[Zakir Husain (politician)|President Zakir Hussain]] died in office, the Vice President [[V. V. Giri]], acted as the President. Later, Mr. Giri resigned as the Vice President. The CJI, Justice [[Mohammad Hidayatullah]] then became the acting President of India. As per the convention, the senior-most judge of the Supreme Court became the acting CJI. When the newly elected President took office a month later, Justice Hidayatullah reverted as the Chief Justice of India
==List of Chief Justices of India== {{Main|List of Chief Justices of India}}
==Remuneration== The [[Constitution of India]] gives the power of deciding remuneration as well as other conditions of service of the Chief Justice to the [[Parliament of India]]. Accordingly, such provisions have been laid down in ''The Supreme Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act, 1958''.<ref name="HC and SC Judges Salaries and Conditions of Service Amendment Bill 2008">{{cite web|title=The High Court and Supreme Court Judges Salaries and Conditions of Service Amendment Bill 2008|url=http://www.prsindia.org/uploads/media/1230018357/1230018357_The_High_Court_and_Supreme_Court_Judges__Salaries_and_Conditions_of_Service__Amendment_Bill__2008.pdf|publisher=PRS India}}</ref><ref name="SC Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act 1958">{{cite web|title=Supreme Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act 1958|url=http://mha.nic.in/pdfs/SC%28salary_and_condition_of_services%29act_1958.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, India|accessdate=23 July 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104092701/http://mha.nic.in/pdfs/SC%28salary_and_condition_of_services%29act_1958.pdf|archivedate=4 January 2011}}</ref> This remuneration was revised in 2006-2008, after the sixth central pay commission's recommendation.<ref>http://www.prsindia.org/uploads/media/vikas_doc/docs/1241592662~~1230018357_The_High_Court_and_Supreme_Court_Judges__Salaries_and_Conditions_of_Service__Amendment_Bill__2008.pdf</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

A '''cigarette tax stamp''' is any adhesive stamp, metered stamp, heat transfer stamp, or other form or evidence of payment of a cigarette tax.<ref>[http://www.search.state.ny.us/search?q=cache:I2tZnmnVylgJ:www.tax.state.ny.us/pdf/2004/altab/cg15_904.pdf+cigarette+tax+stamp&access=p&output=xml_no_dtd&site=default_collection&ie=UTF-8&client=nystate_frontend&proxystylesheet=nystate_frontend&oe=UTF-8 Cigarette tax stamp]</ref> A cigarette tax stamp is a specific example of a [[revenue stamp]].
The 1978 Contraband Cigarette Act prohibits the transport, receipt, shipment, possession, distribution, or purchase of more than 60,000 [[cigarette]]s (300 cartons) not bearing the official tax stamp of the [[U.S. state]] in which the cigarettes are located.

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} The '''Commission on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons''', also known as the '''McKay Commission''', was an independent commission established in the United Kingdom to consider issues arising from [[devolution in the United Kingdom]] and their effect on the workings of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]. In the statement made by the government when setting up the commission, it referred to the [[West Lothian Question]], a term coined in 1977 to refer to anomalies existing in the pre-devolution government of the UK.{{cite web|title= Commission on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons|url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons-vote-office/5-DPM-Devolution.pdf|date=12 January 2012|website=parliament.uk|author=Mark Harper|author-link=Mark Harper}} The commission, chaired by [[Sir William McKay]], considered changes to the procedures of the House of Commons in relation to legislation that only affects part of the UK. It started its work in February 2012 and reported in March 2013. It recommended that future legislation affecting England but not other [[countries of the United Kingdom|parts of the UK]] should require the support of a majority of MPs sitting for English constituencies.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-21920010 BBC News, ''England-only laws 'need majority from English MPs' '', 25 March 2013]. Retrieved 25 March 2013 ==Background== {{main|West Lothian question}} The term "West Lothian question" refers to issues concerning the former ability of members of parliament from [[Westminster constituencies|constituencies]] in Northern Ireland, [[Scotland]] and [[Wales]] to vote on matters that affect only people living in England and therefore have no direct consequence on their constituents, whilst being unable to influence matters that affect their own constituencies. Anomalies of this kind are considered to have been made more apparent by the [[Devolution in the United Kingdom|devolution of power]] from [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Westminster]] to the [[National Assembly for Wales]], the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]] and the [[Scottish Parliament]]. The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] manifesto for the 2010 general election included a commitment to introduce the idea of "[[English votes on English laws]]" and the party had previously explored this issue through a taskforce led by [[Kenneth Clarke]].{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/7481906.stm | title=Tories consider MP voting changes | work=BBC News | date=1 July 2008 | accessdate=1 April 2013}} Scottish Conservative [[Malcolm Rifkind|Sir Malcolm Rifkind]] has also written about the issue, proposing an English grand committee as a possible solution.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/party-leader-welcomes-rifkind-s-elegant-west-lothian-answer-1.843791 |title=Party leader welcomes Rifkind's 'elegant' West Lothian Answer |publisher=Herald Scotland |date=3 October 2007 |accessdate=25 January 2012}} The [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] manifesto included a commitment to address the status of England as part of wider UK constitutional reforms. The 2010 [[Conservative – Liberal Democrat coalition agreement|coalition agreement]] between the parties included a commitment to establish a commission to examine the West Lothian question.{{cite web |url=http://programmeforgovernment.hmg.gov.uk/files/2010/05/coalition-programme.pdf |title=Programme For Government |publisher=Programmeforgovernment.hmg.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=25 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100919110641/http://programmeforgovernment.hmg.gov.uk/files/2010/05/coalition-programme.pdf |archivedate=19 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }} Plans for a commission were announced in September 2011 and its membership was disclosed in January 2012. ==Membership== The commission was set up with six members, described "independent, non-partisan" experts. The members were:{{cite web|url=http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/wg-news-1.nsf/0/E0FF9F7AD70F18878025798900394E10?OpenDocument |title=Article |publisher=Wired-gov.net |date=18 January 2012 |accessdate=25 January 2012}} [[File:Yvonne Galligan.jpg|thumb|100px|Galligan]] *Sir William McKay, former Clerk of the House of Commons *Sir Geoffrey Bowman, former First Parliamentary Counsel (resigned 20 June 2012){{Cite web |url=http://tmc.independent.gov.uk/commissioners/ |title=Commissioners |publisher=The McKay Commission |accessdate=26 June 2012}} *Sir [[Stephen Laws]], retiring First Parliamentary Counsel *Sir [[Emyr Jones Parry]], former UK Ambassador to the United Nations *Prof Charlie Jeffery of the [[University of Edinburgh]] Academy of Government *Prof [[Yvonne Galligan]] of [[Queen's University Belfast]] ==Terms of reference== The terms of reference for the commission were: {{quote|To consider how the House of Commons might deal with legislation which affects only part of the United Kingdom, following the devolution of certain legislative powers to the Scottish Parliament, the Northern Ireland Assembly and the National Assembly for Wales.}} ==Publication of report== The report of the commission was published on 25 March 2013. Its main conclusions are:[http://tmc.independent.gov.uk/news/the-mckay-commission-report-on-the-consequences-of-devolution-for-the-house-of-commons-published-25-march-2013/ The McKay Commission’s Report on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons published – 25 March 2013]. Retrieved 25 March 2013 *"Evidence suggests that people in England feel unhappy with present arrangements, which take too little account of their grievances. A response is necessary. *"Decisions taken in the Commons which have a separate and distinct effect for England (or England-and-Wales) should normally be taken only with the consent of a majority of MPs sitting for constituencies in England (or England-and-Wales). *"That principle should be clearly set out in a resolution of the House of Commons, and House procedure should be changed to encourage MPs to follow this approach. *"A range of procedural changes is suggested, all of which would allow the English voice to be heard. Some of them involve committees on bills, with majorities reflecting the party balance in England (or England-and-Wales). Others take the form of motions on the floor of the House. They are not a single package but a menu from which choices can be made to suit the circumstances of a particular bill. *"A select committee on Devolution should be appointed, which would (among other things) assist the House to hold UK ministers to account for their responsibilities in connection with devolution and their relations with the devolved administrations. *"Under the Commission's recommendations, no MPs would be prevented from voting on any bill, and the right of the House as a whole to make final decisions would be preserved. However, there would also be scope for additional roles for MPs from England (or [[England and Wales|England-and-Wales]])." Sir William McKay said:
Our proposals retain the right of a UK-wide majority to make the final decisions where they believe UK interests or those of a part of the UK other than England should prevail. We expect that governments will prefer compromise to conflict.
==See also== *[[Governance of England]] *[[Devolved English parliament]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://tmc.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/The-McKay-Commission_Main-Report_25-March-20131.pdf Commission Report], published 25 March 2013 *[http://tmc.independent.gov.uk/ The McKay Commission] official website *[http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN02586.pdf The West Lothian Question – House of Commons Library Standard Note] {{Devolution in the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Devolution in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Constitution of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Constitutional commissions]] [[Category:2012 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2012 in British politics]] [[Category:House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Politics of England]] [[Category:Politics of Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Politics of Scotland]] [[Category:Politics of Wales]] [[Category:English nationalism]] [[Category:Government of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2013 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2013 in British politics]]

revision.text: '''Constitutional review''', or '''constitutionality review''' or '''constitutional control''', is the evaluation, in some [[country|countries]], of the [[constitutionality]] of the [[law]]s. It's supposed to be a system of preventing violation of the rights granted by the constitution, assuring its efficacy, their stability and preservation.{{cite book|url=http://www.concourts.net/The%20Constitutional%20Review%20sample.pdf|last=Mavcic|first=Arne|title=The Constitutional Review|year=2001}} == Distinction == There are very specific situations in which the constitutional review differs from [[common law]] to [[civil law (legal system)|civil law]], as well as the judicial review in general.{{cite web|url=http://www.nyujlpp.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/John-E-Ferejohn-Constitutional-Review-in-the-Global-Context.pdf|title=Judicial Review in Global Context|author=Ferejohn, John E.|publisher=NYU Law|accessdate=6 July 2012}} {{main article|judicial review}} == Concept == In the countries that have written and [[Rigid Constitution|rigid constitutions]], they (the constitutions) represent the supreme norm of the [[juridical order]], sited on the top of the pyramid of norms. It's named as ''fundamental law'', ''supreme law'', ''law of the laws'', ''biggest law''. That biggest law asks for more difficult and [[legal procedure|formal procedures]] for updating than the other juridical norms (named ''sub-constitutional''). Although this is usually characterized as a civil law speciality, some of the concepts here can be [[inheritance (computer science)|inherited]] from common law countries which have written constitutions; for instance, USA, that, paradoxally, in timeline, was the first to adopt the diffuse review. {{main article|constitution}} == Application == The judicial control of ''constitutionality'' applies to the [[normative act]]s too.{{cite web|url=http://www.venice.coe.int/docs/2010/CDL-AD(2010)039rev-e.pdf|title=Study on Individual Access to Constitutional Justice|publisher=Council of Europe - Venice Commission|accessdate=6 July 2012}} == History: ''Marbury v. Madison'' - the first precedent == The first [[precedent]] in which the American [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] asserted its power of constitutional control was the ''Marbury v. Madison''. {{main article|Marbury v. Madison}} ==See also== * [[Constitutional review in Germany]] * [[Constitutional Review Commission (Tanzania)]] * [[Judicial interpretation]] * [[Rule of law]] * [[Rule According to Higher Law]] * [[List of constitutional courts]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Judicial review]]

The '''Daimler–Hyundai Truck Corporation''' was a joint venture established between [[Daimler AG]] and [[Hyundai Motor Company]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Hyundai Motor & DaimlerChrysler Unveil New Joint Truck Company |publisher=News World (Korea) |date=2001-08-01 |url=http://www.newsworld.co.kr/cont/0108/53.html |accessdate=2006-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928220943/http://www.newsworld.co.kr/cont/0108/53.html |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref> in 2000 to produce high-tech middle-range trucks and buses in the Korean market beginning in 2004.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Hyundai Motor and DaimlerChrysler Break Ground for New Commercial Vehicle Engine Plant | publisher = [[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai Motor Co.]] | date = 2001-11-14 | url = http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/11-14-2002/0001841750&EDATE= | accessdate = 2006-11-30 }}</ref>
After numerous delays and disputes,<ref>{{cite news | title = Hyundai wants end to Daimler's Beijing deal | url = http://english.people.com.cn/200310/15/eng20031015_126100.shtml | publisher = [[People's Daily|People's Daily (China)]] | date = 2003-10-15 | accessdate = 2006-11-30 }}</ref> the planned venture was cancelled in 2004, with DaimlerChrysler selling its 10.65 percent stake in Hyundai Motor.<ref>{{cite news | title = Daimler, Hyundai Separating | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A22726-2004May12.html | publisher = [[The Washington Post]] | page = E02 | date = 2004-05-13 | accessdate = 2006-11-30}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
